brief_summary.textblock:
In this study the investigators aim to assess whether transcranial direct current
      stimulation (tDCS; a safe and non-invasive method for modulating the activity of specific
      brain regions) when applied over the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) or the dorsolateral
      prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) is able to enhance decision-making and decrease impulsivity in
      healthy participants.

detailed_description.textblock:
In this single-blind, sham-controlled study, the investigators aim to assess whether
      transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS; a safe and non-invasive method for modulating
      the activity of specific brain regions) when applied over the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) or
      the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) is able to enhance decision-making abilities and
      reduce impulsivity levels in healthy volunteers.

      The investigators hypothesize that tDCS particularly over the left OFC and the right DLPFC,
      in comparison to sham rTMS, will significantly enhance decision-making and decrease
      impulsivity.

      The investigators will enroll 110 healthy individuals aged 18-45 years. These individuals
      will be assessed with several instruments (including clinician-administered, self-reported
      and computer-based) Assessments will be carried out before and after a 30-minute tDCS
      session.

      Our study could result in a better understanding of the neurobiological basis of well-known
      predisposing factors for suicidal behavior in subjects at high risk for suicide, namely
      decision-making deficits and heightened impulsivity. Undoubtedly, a novel safe and
      non-invasive method for decreasing the vulnerability to suicidality among high risk
      individuals would be a promising therapeutic intervention for suicide prevention.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Men or women aged 18 to 45 years

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Presence any psychiatric and/or neurological illness

          -  Psychoactive substance abuse/dependence in the past 6 months

          -  Current use of medication(s) that might influence cognition and/or affective status

          -  Presence of an uncontrolled medical disease (e.g., cardiovascular, renal)

          -  Pregnancy and/or lactation

          -  Specific contraindication for tDCS (e.g., metallic head implant).

intervention.description: Anode placed over the OFC or the DLPFC and cathode placed over the occipital region

facility.name: Neuromodulation Research Clinic, Douglas Mental Health University Institute

clinical_study.official_title: Decision-Making, Impulsivity and Suicidality: A Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation Study in Healthy Subjects

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the Iowa Gambling Task
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and after a 30-minute tDCS session

reference.citation: Beeli G, Casutt G, Baumgartner T, Jäncke L. Modulating presence and impulsiveness by external stimulation of the brain. Behav Brain Funct. 2008 Aug 4;4:33. doi: 10.1186/1744-9081-4-33.

Boggio PS, Campanhã C, Valasek CA, Fecteau S, Pascual-Leone A, Fregni F. Modulation of decision-making in a gambling task in older adults with transcranial direct current stimulation. Eur J Neurosci. 2010 Feb;31(3):593-7. doi: 10.1111/j.1460-9568.2010.07080.x. Epub 2010 Jan 25.

Fecteau S, Pascual-Leone A, Zald DH, Liguori P, Théoret H, Boggio PS, Fregni F. Activation of prefrontal cortex by transcranial direct current stimulation reduces appetite for risk during ambiguous decision making. J Neurosci. 2007 Jun 6;27(23):6212-8.

Hecht D, Walsh V, Lavidor M. Transcranial direct current stimulation facilitates decision making in a probabilistic guessing task. J Neurosci. 2010 Mar 24;30(12):4241-5. doi: 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.2924-09.2010.

Sela T, Kilim A, Lavidor M. Transcranial alternating current stimulation increases risk-taking behavior in the balloon analog risk task. Front Neurosci. 2012 Feb 14;6:22. doi: 10.3389/fnins.2012.00022. eCollection 2012.
